column1: I implemented an algorithm on my COVID-19 forecasting project to compile a subset of similar states that have similar population densities to use as a training set for predictions for one specific state. First
column2: a population density tolerance had to be specified (plus or minus a certain number of people)
column3: then a minimum recovery factor would need to be specified to eliminate states that have not seen recovery from the training set
column4: a defined starting point of the outbreak measured in percent of the maximum number of outbreaks per state
column5: and finally a value to separate the training and testing data. The similar population densities and minimum recovery factor worked by filtering out only the states that met the thresholds so that a suitable subset would be generated
column6: and then the other two parameters were tweaked in order to surround the maximum curve of the normalized data to determine how the specific group of states socially distanced to reduce the number of new cases per day. This algorithm was able to provide results and predictions for numerous states currently at their peak of new outbreaks.

column1: What tools have you used?
Process Improvement - Describe a project in which you improved something
In my recent project on COVID-19 forecasting
column2: I noticed that as I working on it and new data became available
column3: I would have to consistently keep cleaning the data because there were occasional new missing values. This made updating the project very tedious and difficult to update. To fix this issue
column4: I took initiative by streamlining the data pipeline
column5: by adding a function that would fill in the missing data with the average of the data points directly before and after the missing data and replicate this value to override the missing values. The function could also detect if the missing data were at the end of the dataset (so there would be no data after to average with) and simply replicate the last known data point to the missing data. As a result
column6: I was able to automate the null value replacement in the data cleaning process and quickly update and run the model without problems for all future data updates.

column1: I also noticed that the model took a very long time to run and there was a lot of redundancy in the function
column2: and was very difficult to follow. In order for the code to be presentable and easier for others to understand
column3: I streamlined the data pipeline: re-evaluated the process by which the model ran. For example
column4: initially I had numerous locations in the code where I re-imported the code
column5: cleaned it
column6: then realized I needed data that I had processed out of the dataframe
column7: so I had to reimport it and clean it again in a slightly different way. Instead of having the model run this way
column8: I fixed it so that the function to clean the data outputted two different dataframes so the process would only need to run once.

column1: When I was working as a Design Engineer at Denso
column2: I was once tasked with finding a proper color film to use with a light to determine which film would give us lighting colors within our customer specifications. I was given a booklet with hundreds of pages of film colors and expected to take all day to keep measuring them until I found one that would give us lighting within our color specifications. After testing films
column3: I noticed one color gave us specifications considerably to the left
column4: and another color gave us specifications considerably to the left. I decided to measure both of these colors overlaid on one another simultaneously and noticed that the specs met our color tolerance. However
column5: due to the double thickness of the film
column6: this filtered out too much of the lighting intensity. I then ended up flipping through the booklet and finding the closest color I could find to the two colors overlaid on one another and tested that one
column7: and we had met all requirements. I was able to jump right to the color that met our specifications in a fraction of the time through this approach.

Describe COVID-19 Project with CHCOC
With the COVID-19 pandemic in full swing
column2: people of all races and ethnicities are catching the virus. However
column3: although Hispanics represent 30% of Colorado's population
column4: 60% of cases recorded are of hispanic people. Through this project
column5: I worked with Halvatzis Consulting and the Colorado Hispanic Chamber of Commerce to investigate possible factors on why hispanic people are disproportionately affected by the virus. My role was to investigate education
column6: environmental factors
column7: and food deserts of largely hispanic areas in Colorado to see if there is any correlation between the factors. So far
column10: there is a significant number of people in Colorado not fluent in English
column11: and graduation rates for hispanic people are generally lower in largely populated areas (which also happen to be where the most hispanic people live). As for food deserts
column12: the top two census tracts with the highest number of people that live more than 20 miles away from a supermarket and have no access to a vehicle are both in Costilla county
column13: which has a 60% hispanic population. In terms of environmental factors
column14: I found data sources on air quality
column16: and soil quality. The zip code 80216 has the highest air pollution in the county
column18: and also happens to be a food desert (urban area with more than 1 mile away from supermarkets/healthy food sources). I plan on doing a group project with members from my cohort on soil and water quality as the data sources are too large and complicated to tackle in the time frame of this project.

column1: Describe COVID-19 Forecasting project
I used a subset of states similar in population density to states currently at their peak of daily new cases of COVID-19 to get insight on the most effective means of social distancing
column2: from workplaces
column3: activity at parks
column4: etc. and to forecast the future number of new cases based on sustained levels of public activity. Based on the state
column5: the findings were different. For example
column6: reducing public activity in parks seemed to be the most effective way to reduce covid infections.

column1: Describe Electricity generation renewable project
In this project
column2: I used electricity generation data from countries all around the world from 1980 to 2017 to investigate if the proportion of electricity generated with renewable resources was significantly improving. My main focus was to see if the top most developed countries in the world showed a statistically significant change
column3: as my goal was to see if the countries who had the resources to go renewable were doing so. I also chose countries of specific countries to get trends for specific regions and found that the changes throughout the years were not statistically significant enough to prove that the proportions have been increasing.

column1: If you could do one thing done differently on your project
column2: what would it be?

column1: In my COVID-19 forecasting project
column2: one thing I would have done differently would be to use results on a county by county basis as opposed to a state by state basis. This would have taken more time as it would turn a dataset of 50 states into over 3000 counties
column3: but by using a state by state basis
column4: I was forced to make the assumption that each state had the same distribution of population densities. Moreover
column5: when I started the project only several states were currently at their peak of new cases
column6: and now nearly half of the states are
column7: so there is a much more limited selection of recovered states to choose from to make predictions for each state. By using a county by county basis instead of state by state
column8: there would be a much greater selection available of recovered counties with similar population densities to draw more accurate insights from.

column1: One challenge I faced during my COVID-19 project was strange results for some states when I ran my model on them. Sometimes I would not see any improvement in the number of new cases with very low social distancing
column2: and sometimes the estimation for the state was a higher number of new cases with maximum social distancing
column3: which doesn't make any sense. I solved this problem by paying close attention to the subset of the states chosen to draw insights for a state
column4: normalizing the date so that the curves of each state were as closely aligned as possible
column5: and then tweaking the training data so that it didn't capture decreasing trends in social distancing as people returned to public activity after the peak of new case in a certain state in the subset
column6: but not so much that the factors that drove the peak down in the first place were excluded. In the end
column7: I was able to get viable results for many of the states currently at their maximum number of new cases.

column1: How did you normalize the dates?
Soft challenge:
During my time at Galvanize
column2: I was required to present my final capstone project in 4 minutes or less and make my project interpretable to the audience in that time frame. During the early stages of my project
column3: my model was so complicated that it included a random forest that consisted of every single feature time lagged
column4: comprising a dataset of 188 features. In this stage
column5: my model was so uninterpretable that it took multiple sessions of explaining what I did
column6: so there was no way I was going to be able to explain this to an audience in 4 minutes or less. After reducing the time lagged features to simplify so that only the target variable
column7: which was the number of daily new cases
column9: I reduced the number of features from 188 to 30 and was still getting viable results
column10: and the model was much easier to explain. In the end
column11: I was able to present and explain my project thoroughly while meeting the time requirement.

column1: Tell me about a time when you fixed or improved a process or procedure
In my Galvanize Data Science Immersive program
column2: I was working on a case study involving a ride share service and trying to get insights as to why certain customers were churning and to find the most important features. I noticed that there was a very heavy skew towards a 5 star rating
column3: so instead of using the star rating as a feature
column4: I suggested that our team separates this into 3 different categories: 5 star
column5: less than 5 star
column6: or unknown. Ultimately
column7: my feature engineering was able to detect a better level of churn. In most of the algorithms that we implemented
column8: a low (less than 5 star rating) rating was detected as one of the top most important features. Had we have left the numerical value
column9: we probably would have missed this insight.

I find lists and dictionaries helpful. A list is helpful when iterating through a function and then tracking the changes to the variable as it goes through. This can be helpful to input to create scatter plots. Dictionaries are helpful when replacing large quantities of text or storing counts.

column1: Functional approach is better when what you are trying to do can be characterised as a verb; Object oriented when what you are trying to do is a noun. Functional oriented paradigms treat programs as mathematical functions and avoids mutable data. Object oreinted paradigms treat programs as interacting with objects/datafields and their interactions with one another.

Big data is data that is too big to work with on one machine. I think what makes it difficult to work with is the sheer volume and the difficulty in examining all contained values quickly. An example of how I worked with Big Data was processing tweets using Spark on a case study.

column1: Explain the concept of MapReduce in simple to understand language. How does MapReduce help analyze data that's distributed?
MapReduce is the programming model which divides the data into separate sections/clusters to process and then aggregates them all at the end to expedite processsing.
Our company presently uses MapReduce
column2: but we've heard that Spark is better. Why is that? And how does Spark work with and return results on distributed data?

column1: If one cluster fails
column2: Spark can still generate a result due to resilient distributed datasets (RSS). Spark features an advanced DAG engine that makes it much faster to process data. Spark limits the number of times read from and writing to disk
column3: whereas MapReduce does this with every operation
column4: making it slower.

Supervised Learning
What is the bias/variance trade-off in supervised machine learning? What process do you follow to ensure your model generalizes well to unseen data?
Bias/variance trade off is the concept by which if a model fits the training data very well
column2: it will likely overfit the test model as the model will be picking up on random noise as opposed to the actual signal in the data. The process I follow is to split the data into a training and test set
column3: and sometimes cross validate and calculate the MSE of each model
column4: choosing the test parameters resulting in the lowest MSE of the test data.

column1: Explain how the decision tree (classification) algorithm works.
It is a greedy algorithm that splits the data a defined number of times to split the data into several different nodes with different characteristics in data.
How does a random forest differ from a single decision tree? Why are its predictions more generalizable?
A random forest utilizes a number of decision trees in a model which have several randomly generated components
column2: reducing ovefitting and variance through the ensemble. It's predictions are more generalizable because it uses a number of analses as opposed just to one so it cuts out on the variance.

column1: What is an ensemble method? What ensemble models do you know? How does each achieve a low-bias
column2: low-variance prediction?

column1: An ensemble method is a statistical model that uses a group of models to perform regression/classification to reduce variance and increase flexibility in the data. Random forest
column2: Bayes
column3: bagging

column1: Each achieves a low-bias
column2: low-variance prediction by aggregating multiple models to get a more generalized result that picks up more on the trend of the data as opposed to certain anomolies that may be present in any one model selected.

column1: How would you explain a latent topic to a layperson?

Using intra-cluster distance and inter-cluster distance. A good model will have a large inter-cluster distance and a small intra-cluster distance.

column1: 10. What motivating mindset has helped propel you forward when overcoming challenges?

I am motivated by seeing a project grow to fruition and leaving something it in a better place than i found it in. I decided to come to Galvanize after a lot of research regarding its reputation in the Denver data science community and the fact that it would get me the career change and location change that I have been looking at for many years
column2: and much more quickly than a Master's Degree (which I was originally looking at). I wanted a career change because I felt detached and uninterested in my engineering career and any paths going forward with it did not appeal to me. The math and programming I learned in college played virtually no role in my career and I wanted to make use and explore these talents and passions more. In the longer term
column3: I want to establish a data science career in the Denver
column4: CO or Boulder area and continue exploring my newfound passion and learn all that I can and make a difference in the world.

Although I enjoyed the ample challenges and problem solving opportunities in my engineering career

column3: so I did some soul searching to plan out my next move. I decided to pivot into data science to carry forward my critical thinking and passion for problem solving into a job that I will be excited about.

column1: Describe a situation where you’ve had a conflict with another individual
column2: and how you dealt with it.  What was the outcome?

column1: I find that the best way to handle conflict is to remain calm and patient while walking through the process of causing the problem one step at a time instead of telling anyone they're wrong. For example
column2: my experience in Galvanize involved several case studies
column3: which were fast paced team projects that we only had one day to do. When our team's code wasn't working
column4: sometimes things would get heated due to the stress of the time constraints. For example
column5: when I was having problems uploading our project to GitHub when I was in charge of it. Instead of getting defensive
column6: I asked for feedback from the team on how they would suggest doing it
column7: and shared my screen to go over my thought process. Ultimately
column8: we were able to move through the conflict and resolve the problem together without wasting time arguing.

column1: There was a time in which I received a graded homework assignment back from my Professor that was not graded correctly. He took points off because he did not see one of the problems in the assignment that I did do. I talked to him once
column2: but he denied his mistake and said he graded a problem on the problem set that I did not have done. After checking this on my own
column3: I saw that I did in fact
column4: do both problems
column5: the one that he claimed he did not grade and the one he said he graded instead. Before going up to talk to him for a second time
column6: I ensured that I was correct by double checking the homework problems I did matched the problem set
column7: and approached him asking if he could tell me specifically the 3 problems that he did grade
column8: instead of claiming that he graded my homework wrong. Through this approach
column9: he saw that he in fact made a mistake and gave me full credit for the homework assignment that I in fact did

column1: What’s the biggest mistake you ever made and how did you try to fix it?
Last year
column2: I was the treasurer of the MTU Aquanauts scuba club. During the beginning of the year
column3: I was in an officer transition period in which I was being trained on how to be a treasurer. There were signs up on campus that all campus organizations had to engage in a re-registration process in order to claim campus activities funding
column4: but I assumed that the President or Vice President would take care of it and tell me if I had to do anything. Eventually the re-registration deadline passed and it turned out that the president or the other officers did not re-register us
column5: and it looked as though we were going to lose all of our funding for the year. I got into contact with the president about this ordeal
column6: and we discussed our problem with the student activities staff. It turns out that this procedure was different than in past years
column7: and this problem was common amongst other campus organizations and we were given an extension on the re-registration process. Although our group’s funding was highly jeopardized due to this miscommunication
column8: it all worked out in the end
column9: although it was a close call. In order to keep this from ever happening to our organization ever again
column10: I created a officer transition checklist including re-registration procedures for the treasurer transition packet to keep this situation from ever occurring again. From then on
column11: I made a point of keeping in very close communication with club officers.

column1: Tell me about a time when you had to adjust to a classmate's or colleague's working style in order to complete a project or achieve your objectives.
For design reports
column2: I have always been used to having the actual report on dropbox or another shared drive
column3: and having team members open the report and conduct revisions as they please. This has always worked for me
column4: and was my preferred method for the process by which reports were compiled and revised. I favored this method because it allowed each of the team members to easily cast their input into the final product. However
column5: this process was not as well received in my senior design project team as it was in prior teams. After hearing out the other team members
column6: this procedure allowed one team member to make contributions to the report that may be miscommunicated information that may be false
column7: and made for a montage of many different writing styles in the final report  instead of written in one voice. I adjusted to their idea of highlighting the changes that each of us makes when revising the reports
column8: and creating a revising schedule and log of changes that is accessible to all team members
column9: not to mention a naming convention
column10: to ascertain that team members do not overwrite each others revisions
column11: and so that other members can approve the changes to the paper before they are added to the paper and not easily seen before the final paper is submitted. I was a bit skeptical about this change
column12: but now I realized that it makes a lot more sense and results in a higher quality product at the end.

column1: o   Models of vehicle dynamics – Did this many times in CAD. It involved using KBE tools to pull hard points of suspension models and map specific components to a skeleton to model specific part motions. I also became proficient with using IPS
column2: for creating dynamic models of flexible tubes/wires for those relevant checks
column3: and so I could delve into brake lines checks when suspension work slowed down.  It only took a few months at Ford when I actually became a resource for other employees trying to learn this process.

column1: o   Constantly working with engineers from different commodities in current role. One of my most frequent tasks is to check clearance from components to component in a vehicle. When there is a clearance requirement violated
column2: I would email the engineers of the relevant components and work with them to come up with a solution. There were times when I even created my own proposal for the engineers to use
